abstract.p: Atlanta Braves defeat St Louis Cardinals, 6-4; other National League results noted (S)

block.p: Tom Glavine, helped by a season-high four St. Louis errors, won his seventh straight start as Atlanta won, 6-4, last night in St. Louis.

Glavine (14-5), unbeaten since June 27 at Montreal, allowed three runs and six hits in six innings. He improved his record against St. Louis to 13-4, including 8-1 at Busch Stadium, where he is unbeaten in 10 starts since Aug. 20, 1990.

Atlanta, 15-5 since the All-Star Game break, had lost two straight for the first time since July 5-6. The Braves, who got a go-ahead, two-run homer from Andres Galarraga, have the major leagues' best record at 67-42. (AP)
MARLINS 2, REDS 1: Mike Redmond hit a two-run double and pitcher Ryan Dempster emerged from his month-long slump last night to lead visiting Florida.
Dempster (10-8) allowed six hits in eight innings for his first victory since July 1. Dempster, chosen for his first All-Star Game last month, had gone 0-4 with a no-decision in his last five starts.
After Dempster escaped threats in the seventh and eighth, Antonio Alfonseca pitched the ninth for his major league-leading 33rd save in 36 chances.
Redmond's second-inning double off Pete Harnisch (3-6) sent Cincinnati to its third consecutive loss, another setback to the Reds' hopes of catching St. Louis in the Central Division.

The Marlins won their third in a row but lost the leadoff hitter Luis Castillo to a leg cramp in the third inning. Castillo, who leads the majors with 46 steals, beat out a grounder for an infield single, then hobbled and sat down holding his right hamstring.
Harnisch allowed eight hits in eight innings as he got his first loss since July 5. Since rehabilitating a weak shoulder, Harnisch has gone 3-2 with a 2.49 earned run average. (AP)
ASTROS 7, EXPOS 6: Chris Truby homered twice and Daryle Ward hit a three-run shot for host Houston, which has a franchise-record 83 homers at home this season.
Truby hit a two-run homer in the third and Ward hit his 15th homer as Houston took a 5-4 lead. Truby added a solo shot, his third, to tie the score at 6 in the sixth inning.
The Astros, who moved from the spacious Astrodome to homer-friendly Enron Field this season, broke the record of 82 set in 1998 with 32 home games remaining this season.
Houston starter Chris Holt left in the fourth inning after getting hit in the left cheek by a line drive off the bat of Peter Bergeron.
Holt left the field under his own power and was taken to a hospital for X-rays, which were negative. He was diagnosed with a bruised cheekbone.
Holt allowed five runs and seven hits in three and two-thirds innings with three strikeouts. He left leading, 5-4, but Wayne Franklin gave up an R.B.I. single to Wilton Guerrero.
Jason Green (1-0) pitched one and two-thirds scoreless innings for the victory. Octavio Dotel got four outs for his fifth save.
The Expos lost for the ninth time in 10 games. (AP)

ROCKIES 8, PHILLIES 1: Todd Helton went 4 for 4 with two homers and four runs batted in, sending Philadelphia to its fourth straight loss and giving host Colorado just its seventh victory in 29 games.
Kent Bottenfield (0-1), acquired Sunday from Anaheim for Ron Gant, allowed five runs and 10 hits in six innings in his 100th career start.
Helton hit a solo homer in the first and a two-run shot in the eighth to raise his National League-leading average to .380.
Julian Tavarez (7-2) allowed one run and four hits in six innings to get the victory.
DODGERS 2 BREWERS 1: Eric Karros hit a tie-breaking single in the eighth inning and Kevin Brown matched his career high with 12 strikeouts as the Dodgers won at home for their third straight victory.

Mark Grudzielanek greeted reliever Juan Acevedo (1-4) with a leadoff single in the eighth and advanced on a groundout before Shawn Green was intentionally walked. Karros followed with a single that went into center field, scoring Grudzielanek.
Mike Fetters (4-1) relieved with two outs in the eighth and watched catcher Todd Hundley throw out Marquis Grisson at second on his first pitch, then finished for the win.
Brown was working on a four-hitter and his 18th career shutout until the Brewers tied the score in the eighth on Raul Casanova's double and Marquis Grissom's single.

RELAFORD IS TRADED: Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Desi Relaford was traded yesterday to the San Diego Padres for a player to be determined, becoming the fourth opening-day starter to leave the team in the past three weeks.
Relaford, 26, was hitting .221 with 3 home runs and 30 runs batted in over 83 games for the Phillies this season. He also committed a league-leading 24 errors.

Taking Relaford's spot on the roster is the All-Star catcher Mike Lieberthal, who was activated after spending two weeks on the disabled list with a sprained left ankle. Lieberthal is hitting .300 with 14 home runs and 60 R.B.I. over 82 games this season. (Bloomberg News)
